title: Fred Carter (rugby league)
text:
Fred Carter (birth unknown – death unknown) was an English professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1910s and 1920s. He played at representative level for <a href="Rugby%20League%20War%20of%20the%20Roses">Yorkshire</a>, and at club level for <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a> (<a href="List%20of%20Leeds%20Rhinos%20players">Heritage №</a>), <a href="Batley%20Bulldogs">Batley</a> and <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford</a> (<a href="List%20of%20Castleford%20Tigers%20players">Heritage №</a>), as a or , i.e. number 2 or 5, 11 or 12, or 13, during the era of contested <a href="Scrum%20%28rugby%29%23Rugby%20league">scrum</a>s.
Background.
Fred Carter was born in <a href="Castleford">Castleford</a>, <a href="West%20Riding%20of%20Yorkshire">West Riding of Yorkshire</a>, England.
Playing career.
International honours.
Fred Carter represented "The Whites" at against "The Reds" in the <a href="1920%20Great%20Britain%20Lions%20tour">1920 Great Britain Lions tour</a> trial match at <a href="Watersheddings">Watersheddings</a>, <a href="Oldham">Oldham</a> on Monday 1 March 1920, and represented "The Whites" at , and scored a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> in the 26-18 victory over "The Reds" in the <a href="1924%20Great%20Britain%20Lions%20tour">1924 Great Britain Lions tour</a> trial match at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Wednesday 9 January 1924, ultimately he was not selected for either tour.
County honours.
Fred Carter won a <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a> for <a href="Rugby%20League%20War%20of%20the%20Roses">Yorkshire</a> while at Batley; he played in the 30-12 victory over <a href="Cumberland%20rugby%20league%20team">Cumberland</a> in the <a href="County%20Championship%20%28rugby%20league%29">County Championship</a> match during the <a href="1921%E2%80%9322%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20Union%20season">1921–22 season</a> at <a href="Thrum%20Hall">Thrum Hall</a>, <a href="Halifax%2C%20West%20Yorkshire">Halifax</a> on Monday 14 November 1921.
Championship Final appearances.
Fred Carter played in <a href="Batley%20Bulldogs">Batley</a>'s 13-7 victory over <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan</a> in the <a href="1923%E2%80%9324%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20Championship%20First%20Division">1923–24</a> <a href="Rugby%20Football%20League%20Championship%20First%20Division">Championship</a> Final during the <a href="1923%E2%80%9324%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%23Championship%20Playoff">1923–24 season</a>, at <a href="The%20Cliff%20%28training%20ground%29">The Cliff</a>, <a href="Broughton%2C%20Salford">Broughton, Salford</a> on Saturday 3 May 1924, in front of a crowd of 13,729.
County League appearances.
Fred Carter played in <a href="Batley%20Bulldogs">Batley</a>'s victory in the <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20League">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20leagues">County League</a> during the <a href="1923%E2%80%9324%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1923–24 season</a>, and as a runner-up during the <a href="1921%E2%80%9322%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20Union%20season">1921–22 season</a> and <a href="1925%E2%80%9326%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1925–26 season</a>.
County Cup Final appearances.
Fred Carter played in <a href="Batley%20Bulldogs">Batley</a>'s 0-5 defeat by <a href="York%20Wasps">York</a> in the <a href="1922%E2%80%9323%20Yorkshire%20Cup">1922–23</a> <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1922%E2%80%9323%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1922–23 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Saturday 2 December 1922, in front of a crowd of 33,719, and played left-, i.e. number 11, in the 8-9 defeat by <a href="Wakefield%20Trinity">Wakefield Trinity</a> in the <a href="1924%E2%80%9325%20Yorkshire%20Cup">1924–25</a> <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1924%E2%80%9325%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1924–25 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Saturday 22 November 1924, in front of a crowd of 25,546.
Club career.
Fred Carter made his début for <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a> against <a href="York%20Wasps">York</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Saturday 12 December 1914, he was transferred from Leeds to <a href="Batley%20Bulldogs">Batley</a> on Thursday 8 January 1920, he made his début for Batley as a , and scored a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> in the 13-0 victory over <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a> at <a href="Mount%20Pleasant%2C%20Batley">Mount Pleasant</a>, <a href="Batley">Batley</a> on Saturday 10 January 1920, during his time at Batley, he scored eighty-two tries; seventy-five playing as a forward; including five <a href="hat-trick">hat-trick</a>s, and a further seven tries playing as a , he played his last match for Batley in the 2-6 defeat by <a href="Hunslet%20R.L.F.C.">Hunslet</a> at <a href="Parkside%2C%20Hunslet">Parkside</a>, <a href="Hunslet">Hunslet</a> on Saturday 3 September 1927, by which time he had become Batley's all-time record try-scoring forward, he was transferred from Batley to <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford</a> for £75 on Monday 26 September 1927 (based on inflation ) (based on increases in average earnings approximately equivalent to £12,460 in 2016), over his career he scored in excess of 100 tries as a forward, this is an outstanding achievement in this era, and may even rugby league's record pre-<a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> try-scoring forward.
